Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY

The Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences and the Division of Materials Research contribute funds to this award. It supports theoretical research and education in active matter. Active matter is composed of many interacting self-driven units, active particles, that individually consume energy and collectively generate motion or mechanical stress. Realizations range from bacterial swarms to epithelial cell colonies to suspensions of artificial colloidal swimmers. The PI will build on her expertise and track record at the interface of soft matter and nonequilibrium statistical physics to investigate three classes of systems:

* Bacterial suspensions as model active systems that can self-organize in fluid and solid-like phases, as well as a rich variety of emergent patterns. Using bacterial suspension as prototype systems, the PI will classify the self-sustained dynamical phases of active matter and elucidate their properties.

* Self-propelled colloids - Ingenious synthetic analogues of living systems have been engineered that consist of colloidal particles propelled by self-catalytic reactions. These systems provide an ideal quantitative testing ground for active matter theories.

* Cell colonies and tissues, with the goal to understand the interplay of cell-cell and cell-extracellular matrix interactions in controlling force generation and transmission, collective migration, and the emergence of the materials properties of living tissues.
This project will have a broad, potentially transformative impact across several fields, from physics to biology and biomedical, chemical and tissue engineering. The collaboration with experimental groups will provide focus to the theoretical research on phenomena of direct interest and relevance in this rapidly growing field.

The research supported by this award will include opportunities for undergraduates, graduate students and postdoctoral researchers. Its highly interdisciplinary nature will provide broad training at the interface between science and bioengineering, opening up a broad spectrum of employment opportunities.


NONTECHNICAL SUMMARY

The Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences and the Division of Materials Research contribute funds to this award. It supports theoretical research and education in active matter. The name "active matter" refers to a class of nonequilibrium systems composed of many interacting units or particles that individually consume energy and collectively generate coherent motion at large scales. An example is a suspension of swimming bacteria. Each individual bacterium is an active particle that propels itself through a fluid or other medium by consuming nutrients. A dense swarm of bacteria behaves collectively as a living fluid and can self-organize in complex regular patterns, exhibit turbulent motion, or "freeze" into a solid-like biofilm. This type of "emergent behavior", where a collection of many interacting entities shows large-scale spatial or temporal organization in a state with novel macroscopic properties, occurs of course also in inanimate matter (for instance, the transition from water to ice as one lowers the temperature), but acquires a new unexplored richness in active systems that are tuned not by an external knob (the temperature), but by energy generated internally by each unit. Active systems span an enormous range of length scales, from the cytoskeleton of living cells, to bacterial suspensions, tissues and organisms, to animal groups such as bird flocks, fish schools and insect swarms.

The ability to turn energy injected at the molecular scale into organized and complex motion and specific functions at the macroscopic scale is a unique mechanical property of the living state. The research supported by this award aims at understanding and harnessing this defining property by answering several questions: Are there "universal" properties in the behavior of living matter, such as the "freezing" of a dense bacterial swarm into a solid-like biofilm or the glassy dynamics of confluent cell layers, that can be described using the tools and ideas of condensed matter physics? Can some of the defining properties of living systems, such as motility or the ability to adapt their response to external stimuli, be reproduced in synthetic constructs? How does the emergent behavior of tissues, such as their mechanical properties, arise from that of individual cells?

The project will have a broad, potentially transformative impact across several fields, from physics to biology and biomedical, chemical and tissue engineering, and benefit society in several ways. For instance, understanding collective behavior of cells during wound healing and biofilm formation will aid in the characterization of how alterations and mutations in individual cells affect collective mechanical properties and may lead to pathologies.

The research supported by this award will include opportunities for undergraduates, graduate students and postdoctoral researchers. Its highly interdisciplinary nature will provide broad training at the interface between science and bioengineering, opening up a broad spectrum of employment opportunities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research supported by this award has advanced our understanding of active matter on many scales. The name ``active matter” has been coined to refer to nonequilibrium systems composed of many interacting entities that individually consume energy and collectively generate coherent motion at large scales.  A simple example is a bacterial suspension. Each bacterium is an active particle that propels itself through a medium by consuming nutrients. A dense swarm of bacteria can behave collectively as a living fluid and flow with no applied forces, self-organize in complex patterns, exhibit turbulent motion, or ``freeze” into a solid-like biofilm. Active systems span an enormous range of length scales, from the cytoskeleton of living cells, to tissues and organisms, to animal groups such as bird flocks. They include chemical and mechanical analogues, such as active colloids: micron-size spheres partly coated with a catalyst that promotes the decomposition of a component of the ambient fluid, turning the colloidal particles in self-propelled microswimmers.

 

Due to the sustained dissipation of internally generated energy, the dynamics of active entities does not obey time reversal symmetry (TRS), which means that movies of active systems run forward and backward in time look different. The assumption of TRS of the microdynamics is at the very foundation of equilibrium statistical physics, hence the lack of TRS requires new theoretical tools. The research supported by this award has furthered the development of such tools, elucidating the novel properties of active systems. It has resulted in 20 publications in refereed journals, including one in Science, one in PNAS, three in Physical Review Letters and one in Physical Review X.

Significant achievements include:

a)        The discovery of an active glass phase tuned by motility. Active particles can assemble into highly packed states, unaccessible in equilibrium. This behavior is relevant to the design of new self-assembled materials and provides a new understanding of bacteria aggregation, that can give insights in the physical mechanism of biofilm formation.

b)        The identification of a novel contribution to the pressure of active systems named  `swim' pressure that describes the flux of propulsive force across a unit area (also proposed simultaneously by the group of John Brady at Caltech). This work has seeded intense research activity on the mechanical properties of active systems, with progress on both the theoretical formulation of effective equations of state and the experimental quantification of the rheology of active fluids.

c)        The development of active models of dense tissues that quantify the relation between the properties of individual cells and the tissue’s rigidity. An important outcome was the prediction of a transition between liquid-like and solid-like states of the tissue driven by cellular shape and cell motility.

d)        The quantification of the dynamics of active fluids and gels built in the lab from component extracted from living cells. These biomimetic materials exhibit life-like properties, such as spontaneous flow and sustained oscillations, that have been described using active matter physics.

The research supported by this award has had broad societal and educational impacts:

a)        In addition to leading to fundamental advances in physics, the research has impacted other fields, from biology to engineering. The work on active particle models will guide the design of new materials with programmed functions and the development of biomimetic micro-machines. The research on microbial assembly can improve our ability to control and direct the formation of biofilms, bacterial communities that are highly resistant to antibiotics. The work on the materials properties of tissues has direct implications to a number of developmental processes, from morphogenesis to wound healing.

b)        Participation in work supported by this project has contributed to the training of four postdocs (two women) and six graduate students. Some of these young scientists have now completed their work at Syracuse University and moved on to careers in academia (faculty at University College London, postdoc at Harvard and at Crick Institute) and the private sector (high school teaching, investment management, scientific consulting).  Through her work on the Board of the Boulder School and as Director of the Soft Interfaces IGERT Program at Syracuse University, the PI has contributed to the development of interdisciplinary models of graduate education and to enhancing diversity in STEM disciplines.

c)        The PI has been visible in the soft matter community and has played a leading role in the profession by co-organizing schools and conferences (2015 Boulder School, 2016 Cargèse School, 2016 ICAM-sponsored international conference in Syracuse), serving as General Member of the Aspen Center for Physics and on the chair line of the APS Topical Group on Soft Matter, GSOFT.  In 2014 the PI co-organized a 4.5-month program at the Kavli Institute of Theoretical Physics at UCSB. Over 100 scientists form various disciplines participated in the program that was instrumental in pushing forward the field.
